title: emf in loop at two different positions

content.question: A loop of wire at location X is moving toward the right with constant speed v in a region of uniform magnetic field <math> <semantics> <mover accent="true"> <mi>B</mi> <mo>â†’</mo> </mover> <annotation>MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaGabmOqayaala aaaa@36CF@</annotation> </semantics> </math> , which is perpendicular to the plane of the loop. The magnetic field region ends at the dashed line, as shown in the figure above. Later, the loop is at location Y and exiting the magnetic field with the same constant speed v. The process is then repeated with the loop moving at a speed of 2v. Which of the following best describes the emf in the loop at the two positions shown when the process is repeated at a speed of 2v?

choices.label: Emf at Location X Emf at Location Y Nonzero and halved Nonzero and halved
Emf at Location X Emf at Location Y Nonzero and doubled Nonzero and doubled
Emf at Location X Emf at Location Y Nonzero and doubled Zero at both speeds
Emf at Location X Emf at Location Y Zero at both speeds Zero at both speeds
Emf at Location X Emf at Location Y Zero at both speeds Nonzero and doubled

content.answer: Emf at Location X Emf at Location Y Zero at both speeds Nonzero and doubled

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
